In famous equation E=MC2, mass & energy are equivalent & mutually convertible as C is constant. Similarly in E=1/2 mv2, mass is constant, therefore motion & energy are equivalent & mutually convertible. Since energy is equivalent to both mass & motion, it can be concluded that mass & motion are equivalent & mutually convertible. Therefore Energy, Mass & motion are equivalent & mutually convertible. In electron positron annihilation mass of electron & positron changes to motion of photons. During pair production motion of photon change to mass of electron and positron. In nuclear reactions also mass changes to motion of neutrons and gamma photons. When meteors enter earth atmosphere they slow down, loss of motion coverts to light & heat photons.  Photons can be converted to mass by pair production.

There is one question that I always have, when do I know when to use GPE=Wh or PE=mgh
you don't have to type in all caps
​ @oofy1362 1 year ago but ikr

hey! i know i'm 2 months late but i just wanted to share my thoughts.  essentially, W and m•g mean the same thing, so those two equations are the same as well. W in the first equation refers to weight, and W = m•g (weight = mass•gravity). this also means that you could interchange these variables if needed, such that GPE = mgh or PE = Wh. also, all potential energy (except for elastic/spring PE) is gravitational and equal to mgh, which could be helpful to remember.  hope this helps!!

P.E is energy which is potential to be converted to another energy. In this case it’s converted to K.E therefore P.E= K.E . You can not find KE here using that formula because u don’t have speed or V.
There is only kinetic energy. One time it is easy to detect (external), while if we regard it as potential it really just is internal kinetic energy.

For x > 0: | x | = x. d/dx (x) = 1. For x < 0: | x | = -x. d/dx (-x) = -1.  | x | is not differentiable at x = 0. This function is called sgn(x) pronounced "signum of x".
